questions.question: If you ………………………… respect, you get respect.
questions.description: In the first conditional, we use a simple present tense in the if-clause and will + first form of the verb in the main clause.

questions.question: If she studies well, she …………………………. good marks.
questions.description: In the first conditional, we use a simple present tense in the if-clause and will + first form of the verb in the main clause.

questions.question: If you ……………………………. to earn more money, you have to work harder.
questions.description: In the first conditional, we use a simple present tense in the if-clause and will + first form of the verb in the main clause.

questions.question: If you ………………………….. him, tell him that I am waiting for him.
If you ………………………….. out, you will not lose that belly fat.
If I ……………………….. more money, I could buy a car.
questions.description: In the second conditional, we use a simple past tense in the if-clause and would/could/might + first form of the verb in the main clause.

questions.question: If it rains, we …………………………….. get wet.
If I …………………………. you, I would not tolerate this.
Had I seen the signal, I …………………………...
questions.description: In the third conditional, we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: If you had told me you were not coming, I ……………………………… waited for you.
If they had found him early, he …………………………….. saved.
If she hadn’t married him, she …………………………….. happy.
